May 2023#

23 Tue#

Bash#

Learnt the following:

  1. Translate (tr): when appending with echo foo >> bar, the final character is a newline (\n). Therefore, the next thing we append appears on the next line. If we don’t want this behavior, we could tr out the new-line character through

    echo "foo" | tr "\n" "FOO" >> bar

    which writes foo(whatever) to the file``bar`` as usual, but then the next thing we append will go right next to foo(whatever) instead of on the next line.

  2. basic calculator bc for float-arithmetics in Bash:

    echo "scale=2;2/100" | bc

    returns .02

  3. sed delimiter: any character following s is the delimiter. For example, sed 's+hell+world+' file.txt is the same as sed 's/hell/world/' file.txt

SLURM#

Went through the following part of OSC documation on SLURM

  1. HPC basics

  2. Storage Documentation

  3. Data Storage –> Overview of File System (this one has a nice table)

  4. Batch System Concepts

24 Wed#

Meeting with Julie#

  1. Don’t get caught up in the details of the loop. Focus on being able to navigate through it; remember what each part does and what files are called to do what (and where they are). Finish the first assignment by next Wednesday.

  2. Nicholas is currently working with XF for PAEA ARA-hpol (part B), so I will probably be working on the GA for ARA-hpol (part A)? Confirm with Amy on Friday.

  3. Should I start looking into AraSim and learn about Birefringence? Confirm with Amy on Friday.

SLURM#

Went through the following OSC documation on SLURM

  1. Batch System Concepts

  2. Batch Execution Environment

  3. Job Scripts

    seems like we don’t really use parallel computing introduced in this? we just submit jobs through job arrays

  4. Job Submission (mostly focused on Job Arrays). In particular, note that for example

    sbatch --array=1-10%4 test.sh

    is going to submit an array of 10 jobs, but the cluster will only run 4 of them at simultaneously (so 1-4, then 5-8, and finally 9 and 10).

Some SLURM options worth remembering:

  1. A stands for account (PAS1960)

  2. N is the number of nodes

  3. t is wall time

  4. n is the number of tasks. Much better explanation on this here and there.

Prolems#

  1. Still a bit unfamiliar with the SLURM directives such as n. Should review the seciont Job Scripts in the future.

  2. Still unfamiliar with parallel computing (multiple nodes and/or mutiple cores). But since we always use only one node per job, I think I don’t have to worry about stuff like srun and sbcast and all other parallel computing commands for now.

Bash#

  1. Comment block like so:

    : << END
    hello world!
    This is another line.
END

  2. Doing arithemetic, note that many operators need to be escaped. For exmaple:

    expr $A \* $B

    returns \(A \cdot B\)
